awd_abstract_narration: In Drosophila embryos, salivary glands arise from a thickened                   placode of cells in the ventral part of the labial segment. After               the placode forms, its cells are invaginated to form a simple                   tubular gland. Within three hours the cells of the gland are                    already differentiated and producing abundant, secreted products.               This simple example of organogenesis provides opportunities to                  examine the interaction between genes that establish the overall                pattern of the embryo and those that direct tissue specific                     development. Dr. Beckendorf's experiments have focussed on the                  role of embryonic pattern forming genes in choosing the location                of the salivary placodes and initiation salivary gland                          development. The goal of the current proposal is to identify                    additional genes that act downstream from the pattern forming                   genes to direct the morphogenesis and differentiation of the                    glands. Three independent approaches will be used to identify                   these new genes: analyzing enhancer trap lines, screening                       deficiency mutant embryos for salivary defects, and searching for               downstream targets of the transcription factor encoded by the for               head gene. These methods should identify a new set of genes that                will help him characterize specific steps in salivary                           development. Because of the short time between initial                          determination and differentiation, he hopes eventually to                       identify many, if not all, of the intervening steps in salivary                 development.
